subject: control: command line tool to retrieve fan status (status/help functions)
commitMessage:
control: command line tool to retrieve fan status (status/help functions)

This is part one of a multipart commit to create a fan control
command line utility to report service status, show target/
actual RPM/PWM info, and manually control single fans.
Currently this only implements "status" and "help" commands
(and makefile). Further functionality will come in subsequent
commits.

Signed-off-by: Mike Capps <mikepcapps@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Matthew Barth <msbarth@us.ibm.com>
Change-Id: I9a9fc5c50edf7981075b59bb526e967e50e67c86

CLI11 is a popular argument parsing library that would be good to use here as you add more and more options.  Lots of examples with https://grok.openbmc.org/search?full=CLI.hpp&defs=&refs=&path=&hist=&type=&xrd=&nn=1&si=full&searchall=true&si=full

added. I'm withholding "--action" flags pending input from Matt B, We may want backward compat with the old fantcl.sh script, thus "fancontrol status" and not "fanctl --status". Notwithstanding, this lib was still able to simplify cmd line args quite a bit.
unless it's just my gerrit config, a few of these lines are too long

Done

I seem to have this problem a lot, I thought it was done automatically. Do I need to enable clang-format vim integration for this? For source files, I've been clang-formatting manually.

In your .vimrc, you can put something like:
augroup gitcommit
    autocmd!
    autocmd Filetype gitcommit setlocal spell textwidth=72
augroup END

You can then also do things like 'gqip' or something similar to reformat an existing paragraph for you.
I don't think you'll need to use sdeventplus since that's for things like timers.
Done
I don't think you'll need phosphor-logging either, since you just print directly to standard out
Done
Done
in the makefile you're building this as phosphor-fanctl?
Done
I may need to remove the EVENT/LOGGING cxx flags here too.
Done
I should remove the loop and just reference field[0]. the value returned is an array, but there should only be one.
Done
this is an errant comment.
Done
Could you throw example output here?

root@p10bmc:~# /tmp/fanctl status
Fan Control Service State   : loaded, inactive(dead)
CurrentBMCState     : xyz.openbmc_project.State.BMC.BMCState.Ready
CurrentPowerState   : xyz.openbmc_project.State.Chassis.PowerState.Off
CurrentHostState    : xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host.HostState.Off

 FAN        TARGET(RPM)  FEEDBACKS(RPMS)   PRESENT     FUNCTIONAL
===============================================================
 fan0             10000      10000/13591      true         true
 fan1             10000      10000/13591      true         true
 fan2             10000      10000/13591      true         true
 fan3             10000      10000/13591      true         true
 fan4             10000      10000/13591      true         true
 fan5             10000      10000/13591      true         true

A tuple or a structure seems more appropriate here, since the values mean different things.  And/Or also, you could uses constants for the indexes. That being said, it isn't really that big of a deal and the end result isn't really all that different anyway.  Maybe Matt has an opinion
Ack pending Matt B's input.

would using raw strings make this any easier?

auto out = R"(
NAME
   fanclt ...
SYNOPSIS
   ...
)";
std::cout << out
Done
Is this supposed to be limited to 50 characters or less?
Done

Nit: If you move main() to the bottom of the file, you can avoid the requirement to declare functions.  Just make sure all called functions are seen before being called going top to bottom.

Not a big deal, but avoids the need to do dual-maintenance on the function names/args.
Done
Global constants are OK, but I think we usually try to avoid global variables.  Could main() just pass this as a parameter instead?
Note: I don't know the phosphor-fan-presence repo very well.  If global variables are frequently used there then please ignore this comment.

Ack-ing this, however changing it will trigger a rebase on 3 more commits and 3-4 more functions. So I want to get some group consensus before I make the change since this is code is for a simple run-and-done utility.
Done
Missing iface param
Done

This line is assuming the following
* path is not empty
* path contains a "/"
* path has at least one character following the last slash

Would probably be safer to check for these conditions.  e.g. check if rfind() returned npos or if rfind() returned the position of the last character.
I will fix this (and all the others), but I am postponing because I don't have a working simics to test the changes.
Done

Missing @return.

Should it define what the 6 values are, since they are in an anonymous array<string> vs. a struct with field names?
Done
Same comment as on line 90.  Maybe there should be a short function that parses the base fan name from a D-Bus fan path, so that logic is common code?
Ack
Check for rfind returning npos?
Ack
Same comment here and 198 as on 182 and 183.
Ack
Now that I think about it, I'm pretty sure CLI11 has all the help options built in so you wouldn't need to write your own.  I think that's what all the other uses of that lib do.

Agreed.  It isn't beautiful output, but it is automatically maintained when you add/remove/rename stuff in the command line interface.  There is info on how to tweak the output here: https://github.com/CLIUtils/CLI11#formatting
ACK, will look into it.
Done

BTW, this script was never made public..what you're doing here is essentially making the script public as a tool included with phosphor-fan-control.

Lets remove any reference to the bash script along with the issue number and just reference that you're creating a fan control command line tool for use in getting the status, manually controlling fans, etc...
Done
I dont see this being used?
Done
Why have the variable `phosphorServiceName` defined above and then just use the same string value here?
the final version has the global var removed
Done
Knowing our primary users of this script, we should look to enhance this error message to best reflect how/why we got this exception we're printing out to them.
Done
Still needs testing?
Done
Doesnt look to be used or necessary?
its used in the final version where this statement is factored into a getStatus() function
Done
What about if its PWM?
Done
This is just getting the "actual" feedback speed.
Done
This adds the help text "display fan-control status", so why not just use this ability from CLI instead of a printHelp?
Done
Nit: extra space
Done
PWM?
Done
Is this used in a subsequent commit?  I don't think it is being used in this commit.  You replaced it on line 234 with a hard-coded "RPMS" string.
Done
If this has been tested, should the comment be removed?
Done
So this is not sometimes PWM like you had it in the previous patch sets?
Correct, the sensor values are always reported in RPM
Matt had asked about the case where it is PWM.  You replied Done.  Is this done in a subsequent commit?

correct, I had major difficulties being able to test in PWM mode so some of the earlier commits don't strictly support both modes. I didn't have the ability to test PWM until about a week ago. I am aware, however, that we generally want each commit to be atomic and complete.

As you add more options, the code within the try is going to get pretty long.

I would recommend refactoring that into one or two functions.  For example, you could define one function that creates the CLI::App and configures it, and a second function that handles the parsed results and calls the associated functions like status().
I can do this, but only for the last commit. Due to the amount of refactoring done for this file, the complexity of the rebase makes it infeasible and error-prone to do here.
Why not phosphorServiceName ?
this was identified by another reviewer and fixed in a subsequent commit. If you want me to backport it to this commit let me know.
If it was introduced here, it should probably be fixed here.
Done

catch (const std::exception& e)

Shouldn't one do that here, and not as some random change in the subsequent commit?
yes in future reviews I will make sure commits stay on topic.
I am not sure where it went, but I remember there being some debate over using endl or '\n'. It is not in the code style or anti-patterns, so ... I guess I move along.

endl forces a flush of the internal buffer to stdio. this application is a simple command-line-driven utility that runs, outputs, and exits, so I wouldn't expect endl would cause diminished performance here.
Yeah, that is fine. I could not find something that said this was a big no no, so all good.

TODO?
Done?
Not yet?
Some later time?
comment was removed in subsequent commit. Will backport if you request.
I will assume it was done some time later, after this commit. :-)
I dont foresee the fanctl tool requiring to put an interface on dbus, shouldnt need this.
Done
I dont believe we have a need to link in filesystem until maybe a future enhancement to fanctl accesses the filesystem for some reason.
Done
Same here, dont think fanctl will ever interact with dbus directly with hosting any objects/interfaces on dbus.
Done
This does not use the format lib in this commit nor do I think fanctl has a reason to does it? Is this used in a future commit?
fanctl doesn't link without this. probably something pulled in from a header.

Ack

Ah, yeah its probably pulled in thru the use of the SDBusPlus util
